Of course, otherwise I wouldn't even comment
@Elithale Shepard Which ones weren't sexist?

The first one, when the woman asks Rihanna about what she was looking for in men, In my opinion it was a normal question, Rihanna reacted as if it was implied that she was looking for a man, her response was rather defensive and came off as rude. When they asked Ariana Grande about making a choice between make-up and cellphone, she took it personally, as if they were saying this is the only things girls care about which wasn't stated anywhere, it was a small talk, funny question, not to mention the fact that the questions they ask the celebs are usually questions that came from fans, and I honestly believe that if there was a woman sitting and asking her the same thing she would have responded differently, also we can't deny the fact that we mostly see Ariana as a person who pays much attention to both make-up and social media (on the cellphone) so I can clearly see why they might ask this (again, not in an offensive way), she could have responded differently in my opinion, also when they said "ladies, learn!" and she responded "boys learn" it was absolutely uncalled for, they were addressing a real issue with girls that only pay attention to beauty and material stuff, and to their defense they clearly seemed happy to learn that Ariana is not that kind of girl, since they've seen too many girls that only care about make-up and cellphone (and they are right by the way, I'm sure even us girls can recall seeing lots of gals like this.) Taylor swift talks about cheering each-other rather than bashing and fighting (ironically, "Bad Blood" which is about rivalry between two girls start playing) and that is just plain hypocritical, n one made her fight with Katy Perry, no one made Cher fight Madonna, and no one made Lil Kim fight Nicki Minaj, the fights between women are not "what people wait for", it's just what happens every once in awhile. Same applies to Katy in the next clip, she proceeds to bash Taylor in her songs and social media yet talks so much about gals empowering each other, again, doesn't make sense, plus I honestly don't see how it's sexist. Katy Perry in the following clip stated she got paid, well, yeah? I mean, of course she got paid, it's not like women don't get paid ever, and Katy saying it as if it was something out of the ordinary, then pardon me, women just won't be entertainers since they won't get paid for it and won't be profitable to themselves nor the producer/label, same applies to men. Serena then made a huge deal out of her being the sports "person" of the year, as if it's not obvious that a woman is a person, which in my opinion sparks segregation between men and women instead of ending it, as long as people like Serena act as if it is something out of the ordinary to consider a woman as a pers on, sexism won't end, the fact stays, that she got there by her own power and if that isn't an indicator that women can and will then I don't know what i s, f sexism was as prominent in her case she wouldn't have gotten there in the first place. We also have Scarlett Johansson which was asked about her diet, what's sexist in here ? - a woman that likes to know a nother woman's secret to her amazing shape? - that's not sexist, that's a compliment, not to mention the fact that this question was asked on behalf of Scarlett's girl fans, since men won't care about her diet honestly. Same applies to Ann's catsuit question, her young girl fan audience cares about hat, he literally wouldn't ask this otherwise, since he is clearly a man and his diet would be different (more building mass and muscle rather than getting thinner waist and stuff like that). and last one, People were referring to Selena as Justin's ex because she as less popular than him at that time, nowadays you will rarely meet a person who refers to Selena as Justin's ex girlfriend, and men who are less famous than their female ex gf are also called "the ex boyfriend of (insert name)" since the women they have dated were how they would be recognized as, so this is not something that solely applies to women, it's applied to everyone, not the best way to memorize some celebs, but for some it's the only way they can remember those people. Now I'm not saying all of he clips in the video weren't sexist, some were honestly even straight up rude and borderline "punchable" if a person tr eated a woman like that, but many other clips shown were just "filler" in my opinion, many of which I think are not even worth mentioning. Also sorry for grammar/spelling errors or typos, my writing can be messy sometimes

And what do you mean by seen to many girls that pay attention to only make-up and cell phone? I'm going to be honest but you seem like the type to rather go by stereotypes rather than actual facts. That's the thing here. Most of these things they asked were very stereotypical and not to mention an invasion of privacy. "If the interviewer was a woman she would've replied differently." About Taylor Swift and Katy Perry. You honestly cannot use their situation to back up your point. Or Nicki's. "Which in your opinion sparks segregation instead of-" Okay, say no more. These are clearly all your opinions. They aren't facts which came from the discussion of the video. They are just your own biased opinions. You do realize in this day an d age that sexists do exist, right? That racists still exist right? Th at homophobic people still exist right? Since you stated my opinion, I will state mine. Unless there is a constant reminder towards something and why, those types of people will always show up. Why on Earth would people get mad ove r a woman talking about bei ng a woman to win an award? Do you realize the point? If you get upset over that then you clearly have a b it of sexism in you. There shouldn't be a reason for you to get mad over that. Of co urse a woman is a person. But how often do yo u see a woman being chosen for it? She felt the need to express her gratitude and hard work on being a woman that earned that title. What exactly is wrong about that? And how exactly does it promote segregation? It doesn't. But I've been getting bashed for weeks in this comment section for what is a reasonable comment. Th e crazy thing is that I'm a feminist and a progressive person, I'm thoughtful re: women's issues, and I believe in women's equality. But someone I am a pariah for my comments. It confounds me.

@marcus24000 "so youre saying its oke to use words out of there meaning and context?" Well, "there" is an adverb used to indicate the position of something, or a pronoun used to introduce the subject in a sentence. "there" is also used at times as an interjection when consoling someone. Correct usage of the word there would be the following "There are many spelling and grammar errors in your comments up there, yet you feel entitled to criticize someone else for making a hyperbole, which is linguistically correct. There, there, don't be too embarrassed." One function the word "there" DOESN'T have is as a possessive adjective. That would have to be "their". Confusing the two words is not linguistically correct.

@Not Sure Yet Thank you for the respectful reply. And I feel like your heart and mind are in the right place. You are looking for a compromise between both parties. Which is rare imo. Most people really just want to satisfy the primal urge to pwn the other side (me included a lot of times). I think we should allow women to be as strong as they want. Women are still individuals afterall. I have a deep philosphy that every individual deserves the right to explore their potential. But nature allows the female stereotype to be more socially driven. With men, we are driven by primal urges. The trick is not to oppress anyone while not giving into bias. The other trick is finding methods we can all agree on. Women typically value comfort and safety and men typically value the thrill of practice. Outliers still apply of course. And I will get to that in a bit. But there has to be a give and take for how seemingly human we allow ourselves to be. The bitter fact that nature will never let us forget is that we are nothing more than sophisticated animals. We prey on something to survive. Whether its plants or animals, or other people on a social level. It's in our nature to both destroy and create. But civilization now dictates that we oppress hateful tendencies. Which factors into a mans drive to a certain degree. If you notice, the angriest SJWs are feminist men. My pseudo-theory implies displacement of hateful energy. Naturally, outliers with the most problems make the loudest outcry (Incels, feminists, LG BT< /b>>, etc.). This is natural. Every majority has its outcasts. Civilization literally needs to isolate outliers to incentivize productivity. Which is why we have a two party system. The majority blames one another, while the most isolated of each extreme is frequently challenged. In that challenge, lies the most productive individuals. Which worked for a bit. But if male potential is capped, you wont see productivity. You see raised pressure and more explosions of problems. I can't speak for women on this. But I think men need the kind of challenge that glorifies our ego. Because what we are facing right now is the kind of challenge that attempts to erase masculine instinct under the guise of comfort and safety. All we are doing is provoking the weaker males into more hostile tendencies. Sorry to say, a functioning system also needs to consider the interests of its most extreme outcasts. Not just because if their productive potential, but destructive as well. They are the rogue elements that get people killed or change the world. And they are most typically males that no one ever acknowledged beforehand. I get that women are unhappy also. And I get that the ideal of a weaker male means less chances of toxic behavior on a day to day basis. But at the end of the day, mans toxicity needs a outlet. Or else we take it out on women. Especially the ones that make us feel the most insecure or oppressed in our behavior. You made one compelling point, about female inventions and their lack of praise. I think the female stereotype is good at working under a system or with systems. Men usually have to establish systems out of discovery or find notivation to follow them. As much as I respect our progress on the matter. Productivity is far more complicated because mass shootings are more worthy of media attention than the countless inventions we made for peace. Sorry to say, men aren't praised for having ideas or creating inventions. We do what we do because we find pleasure in offering relief to others. That's why J.K. Rowlings made such a huge impact with HP. She created something that understood a struggle and provided a vicarious relief through entertainment. I can go on. But I wrote enough to ask for publishing rights lol. But imo, the reason why men need help is not because we are suffering. We NEED to struggle in tolerable amounts that make sense. I would say the same for women, but you have to deal with us on a daily basis. Sorry for the book response. I can get wordy.

@Phill Simmer (Reply was to long 😂😂 I don't know if this sent multiple times---sorry) Coming back to women wanting respect: you've probably heard the old remark, "now go make me a sandwich." Tbh, if a random person on the street just asked me for a sandwich, I would go make them one, because why not?  Kindness is a good thing. If my boyfriend/partner wanted a sandwich, and he just said, "man I'd give anything for a sandwich right now," I'd go make him that sandwich, because I care for that person, and I have generosity in my soul.  But for some reason, that line: g o make me a sandwich, is hurtful beyond reason, to me personally. I don't know why, but it's the phrase that bothers me most; I'd prefer verbal street harassment to that. It's a complete disregard of a person and their feelings.  Its essentially saying, go F yourself, but in the meanest most degrading way possible. It's kicking a man that is down, and it may be just a joke, but I find it extremely offensive. That line probably sums up any issues I have with (sexist) men. Edit: I can't speak for all women, but I don't want men to change themselves.  Men are awesome (not to sou nd weird lol). Some women really do just want to be on top.  Some are selfish, and want to be 'better" than men.  Many are racist. I've hea rd a woman say it was her God-given right to cheat.  Please don't take them seriously. They are not feminists. What I want is for men to change the way they see women.  Value them for being people, and not for how they look.  I know most/many men aren't misogynists, at least not intentionally, but I think our society as a whole needs to change, women included. "The trick is to not oppress anyone while giving in to the bias.  The other trick is finding methods we can all agree on." I agree wholeheartedly.  And I think women should respect men just as much as I think men should respect women.  The women who choose to be angry and hateful may or may not accomplish things, but killing hate with hate … I think it often causes more hate. (Edit: although taking things nicely often doesn't get anywhere either. I guess it has to be balanced.) The sad thing is that we raise our kids in this mess.  Every generation is a fresh and innocent chance to start again.  These children didn't do the things we/our parents did. They should be brought up to work together; educat ed on r acism, sexism, whateversism, and taught that it was wrong.  They could be a chance to start over, but that won't happen, because we're too busy fighting each other to even consider it. The ironic thing is that the same thing keeps happening over and over.  Someone always finds some group to be rude to just because they can, and then they retaliate, and we learn that we should respect a new group of people.  Guess what kids, we should respect colored people, white people, old people, young people, male people, femal e p eop>le, qu eer people, fat people, AND thin people.  Parents, respect your kids. Kids, you also respect your parents. If we made it a policy to just respect ALL people, we wouldn't have to go through it every time. To conclude this: It will be hard to find methods we all agree on. I personally say: be respectful, and be good.  Can't go wrong with that. There are too many fights going on at once… people tr ying to fight sexism that isn't even there end up disrespecting someone, which turns into a whole new fight for someone else who's sick of these millennials treating him like dirt.  The fights are overlapping, and one side's careless bullets hit way more people than intended. I think men and women should strive to be more than just men and women.  They should strive to be good. Good people. Forget gender roles. Just do th e right thing.  Gender differences will appear naturally. They've always been there. But we're above gender roles, and we shouldn't have to conform to them.  They shouldn't even have to conform to us. Just be good, like, yeet. Well, I wasn't planning to write an essay today 😂 ^^^ Sorry, I think a lot.

@Not Sure Yet Wow, you are by far my most favorite opponent in political conversation. You are a believer and you have taken human nature to heart. From what you are showing me, you are person worth respecting. On the sandwich argument. I can can empathize for that. And as much as I want to advocate freedom of speech, I know how being percieved as lesser is disheartening. And as much as I want to say "forget those people, they're assholes", that just keeps the wheel turning. I can see why you chose this argument. The worst thing about it is that there is no real solution present... Except in ways that risk escalation. I can understand that you want to change male perception towards women. And that will happen in time and with practice. But imo, where the lines need fixing is not in the genders, its in the social status. Compare the sex life of a well endowed 30 yr old to a sexually stunted 22 yea r old. Who is more likely to satisfy a wom an? Sex is surprisingly relevant to being a male outcast. From my experience also, men resent being told what to do. But give us a reason to care and masculine force can be directed. The best place to start with men is at the scariest center of our core. The parts that make us insecure about women. Re duce sexual abrasion between the genders, you reduce the nee d for sexual abuse. Respecting all people is a difficult thing. In my experiemce, I can only love and respect so many people at a time. I literally had to acknowledge my inner asshole to function more sanely. And I think t his is common among men. We romanticize love because we don't feel it naturally. We either have certain gifts, find our own methods or find ways to compensate. Worse over, many of those methods or ways have to be misogynistic. We literally have to objectify women in order to communicate the right c ues for sex. Sure, we can respect women and befriend them. But that need for love is so closely re lated to sex, its intoxicating. Those of us that get desperate, we tend to be the worst. Disappointment encourages us to disregard womens needs and focus on our own physical desires. The only point I disagree with you on is gender neutrality. Personally, I don't think we s hould have gender roles, so long as we understand what each role req uires. If a woman can carry 200+ lbs and wants to be a firefighter, you have my support. She may not be conventionally attractive, due to potential masculine features. But that is no fault of the hers. Nature vs. Nurture traded her strengths. But compare her to a male steretype of brawn > brain. They may be intimidated because such strengths are meant to attract women. You can try to change them, but going against their nature will only make them resent you. Unfortunately, norms vs outliers is far more natural than we will ever want. You can post essays btw. In time, I might slow down. But right now, I like discussion. We are both feeding each other rational explanations of our opposing sides. It's healthy imo.

replies.commentText: I think probably the reason is the years of context and hidden meaning behind the question. commentThread.commentText: It's great when people identify as feminists, however, I have to say I respect people who identify as egalitarians more. Feminism solely advocates women's rights (which IS huge), but also limited. Egalitarians believe in the doctrine that ALL people are Equal and deserve the same Rights and Opportunities. It is not constrained by social biases like race, class, gender, sexuality, religion, etc. And the best part in concerning feminism is that if you are an egalitarian you are by default a feminist too. Not vice versa though.

i think we can say in more progressive countries both genders have an equal amount of problems. it's just in other places like third world countries women still have a way harder time to even get rights

+maxebanana Not really no. For sure women in third world countries have it way harder than us that's just a fact. But we're still not quite there in term of social equality and having an equal amount of problems. There's still a lot of what I call casual sexism in society. For example in the psychological struggle of a lot of women. We're a bit hardwired to think and do things a certain way, because of our education in this culture. It's not some really hard and vicious thing like it could be in a third world country but there's a lot of time when we would impulsively act one way and then take a step back and just think "wtf why do I do that. I don't need to do that, it's not my place it's just stupid". With kids for example or with cleaning, just responsibilities as a whole. Even if people don't come up to us and tell us to do them or to take them we just tend to because a part of us think that we should. There's still some social behavior between men and women in everyday life that is a testimony of cultural sexism so I really wouldn't say bot h gender have an equal amount of problems. At least if we talk to gender related problems because of cours e a black man with for example disabilities, a lot of trauma and an unstable income is probably gonna have more problem than a healthy white girl with a rich investor dad. But yeah I do think culturally there's still a lot of things that are fucked and that I hope will be fix because it comes from society and especially our education from the past so maybe our daughter will have that equality that we seek but it's hard to have it for ourselves with the education we got. I mean it just makes sense. Progress is going fast but we're talking about thousands of years of inequality and sexism here it's not gonna fix itself in one hundred years.

@Laureen Berger oh yeah, my bad. i can see casual sexism being a problem. it can still affect women in some ways. to be honest, i only made an assumption from what i see because i myself am from a third world country. i forgot to take into account about other stuff.

For example, what is the biggest insult you can say to someone in middle school? ''You run like a girl!'' or ''Don't be such a girl''. ''Girl'' is literally used as an insult by young kids, because thats how they're raised. And when they are older, they go from ''don't be such a girl'' to ''Don't be such a pussy''. And before I see any comments being like ''I sUpPorT fEmiNisM jUsT nOt FeMinAzi'' theres no such thing as ''modern feminism'' or ''feminazi''. A word doesn't change meaning, it means the same thing it did 70 years ago. A feminist is someone who wants men and women to be equals , nothing else. Someone who is a ''man hater'' or whatever the fuck you wanna call it, ARE NOT FEMINISTS. They're *Chauvinists*. Why is that so hard to understand?? If a nazi said ''I' m a nazi, but I don't mind jews'' does that mean th at ''nazi'' suddenly means people who don't mind jews? No. It means the exact same thing it did before, cause a word can't change meaning because of people who misuse it. Man-haters aren't feminists, so every time you use feminism as an insult or make fun of it, you're not only making fun of the thousands of child brides being sold off and r*ped by grown men every single day, you're also being straight up sexist. End of fucking story.
